data.title: "TextEditor is closed/disposed" messages when using setDecorations
data.body:
I'm using `setDecorations` to render some labels in editors. I've noticed that I randomly see warnings in the dev tools and in the debug console of the main instance of Code (when I'm debugging using the extension host).

I'm calling the code in a timeout so it's very possible the editor is gone away, however I'm trying to guard against this with the following code:

```ts
private update() {
	const labels = this.closingLabels;
	const editor = this.activeEditor;

	if (!labels
		|| editor != vs.window.activeTextEditor
		|| editor.document.isClosed
		|| labels.file != editor.document.fileName)
		return;

	// (snip build some decorations from labels)

	editor.setDecorations(decType, decs);
```

Is there a race here, or is there a better way for me to check whether the editor is valid for setting decorations on?

```text
[Extension Host] Error: TextEditor disposed
    at t.$trySetDecorations (file:///Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:28:3140408)
    at t.e.handle (file:///Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:28:3100044)
    at s (file:///Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:28:1029376)
    at f (file:///Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/out/vs/workbench/workbench.main.js:28:1030031)
    at _combinedTickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:67:7)
    at process._tickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:98:9)
t.logExtensionHostMessage @ extensionHost.ts:335
(anonymous) @ extensionHost.ts:188
emitTwo @ events.js:106
emit @ events.js:191
process.nextTick @ internal/child_process.js:752
_combinedTickCallback @ internal/process/next_tick.js:67
_tickCallback @ internal/process/next_tick.js:98
```

data.title: "Terminal Delete Word Left" sends `^W` to terminal instead of deleting the word (powershell)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open the powershell integrated terminal and write something.
2. Hit `ctrl+backspace` or execute the "Terminal Delete Word Left" command.

A `^W` will show up instead of deleting the word:

![capture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4404199/29248169-249dc298-801a-11e7-8280-6307b692a5cc.PNG)

Also, "Delete Word Right" sends a `D`.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Version 1703 Build 15063.540

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use `"window.zoomLevel": 0.5` in config
2. Select all contents of file (example data https://gist.githubusercontent.com/Miserlou/c5cd8364bf9b2420bb29/raw/2bf258763cdddd704f8ffd3ea9a3e81d25e2c6f6/cities.json)

Issue not present with natural number in `"window.zoomLevel"`.

    "editor.minimap.enabled": true,

    "workbench.activityBar.visible": true,

data.title: Support to preview selected suggestion as inserted text
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.0

I hope there can be a option in user setting, so I can use tab and shit-tab to select suggestions like in vim.

I tried the following keybindings.json 

```
// Place your key bindings in this file to overwrite the defaults
[
  {
    "key": "shift+tab",
    "command": "selectPrevSuggestion",
    "when": "editorTextFocus && suggestWidgetMultipleSuggestions && suggestWidgetVisible"
  },
  {
    "key": "tab",
    "command": "selectNextSuggestion",
    "when": "editorTextFocus && parameterHintsMultipleSignatures && parameterHintsVisible"
  }
]
```

but the following keybinding in the Default Keybindings cannot be removed by configuring the  keybinding.json file.
```
  {
    "key": "tab",
    "command": "acceptSelectedSuggestion",
    "when": "editorTextFocus && suggestWidgetVisible"
  }
```

In vim, selected suggestion is automatically inserted, VSCode do not until I press the enter.

In summary:

1. I want to use tab and shift-tab to select suggestion like I do in vim.
2. selected suggestion can be automatically inserted, changing selected suggestion resulting in replacing the inserted suggestion, and the suggestWidget will not be hide until I press esc or some char after the inserted.(like in vim)

![out](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15049134/29246567-ad067000-8031-11e7-9f3d-1e626f58e654.gif)


Hope my poor english can be understood.

data.title: fix spelling of 'iff' and 'idenifier'
error TS5042: Option 'project' cannot be mixed with source files on a command line.
data.body:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Create a project folder which **contains a space separator character** somewhere in the name 
2. Create a .vscode/tasks.json as the following

```
{
  // See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
  // for the documentation about the tasks.json format
  "version": "2.0.0",
  "tasks": [
    {
      "type": "typescript",
      "tsconfig": "tsconfig.json",
      "group": {
        "kind": "build",
        "isDefault": true
      }
    }
  ]
}
```

3. Create a blank file .vscode/tsconfig.json

Launch build task results in 

```
> Executing task: tsc -p "c:\Temp\Project Space\.vscode\tsconfig.json" <

error TS5042: Option 'project' cannot be mixed with source files on a command line.

Terminal will be reused by tasks, press any key to close it.
```
Task manager shows the launched process as
```
C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe /c ""C:\Users\lsmith1\AppData\Roaming\npm\tsc.cmd" -p c:\Temp\Project Space\.vscode\tsconfig.json"
```
which is missing the quotes around the tsconfig.json file path.

data.title: Scroll position should not change when returning to file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.16.0-insider (0b6da14128b4e61e331193f18786e8db2792a643, 2017-08-11T19:30:08.812Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 6.1.7601
- Extensions: none
---

**Description**
The scroll position moves down as references are retrieved. For large files, the position can be many lines away.

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Set `typescript.referencesCodeLens.enabled` to `true`.
2. Open any TS file (easiest to see when the file contains an enum).
3. View a different file.
4. Return to the original file.

![scroll-codelens](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1007463/29244961-ce0934fe-7f7d-11e7-9722-fcf382066fa5.gif)

data.body:

wordcount|ms-|0.1.0

I noticed that Markdown preview is incredibly slow for me now - sometimes taking near a minute to render. It seems to be a "one time per doc" issue as if I close the preview and open it up again, it works well, but previewing a new Markdown file is slow again.

I'm using files from my blog - here is one example: https://github.com/cfjedimaster/raymondcamdendotcom/blob/master/content/post/2017/08/09/career-advice-for-a-new-web-dev.md

data.title: Minimum not version is not correct on How to Contribute wiki page
data.body:
At <https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#installing-prerequisites>, it says:
> You'll need git and a recent version of Node.JS (any v6.x is recommended, on Windows you need at least v6.x). nvm is also highly recommended.

However, I was not able to build with v6.x. Perhaps the minimum now is v7.x?

data.title: Add empty problem matcher to "Run Dev" task
data.body: Without this, vscode always asks you what to do. When you select an option, it edits this file, so we might as well put a configuration here so it doesn't keep asking.

data.title: How to define a default for a new theme colour?
data.body:
I've added a new feature to my extension and want the user to be able to customise the colour. I figured it makes sense to have it in the `workbench.colorCustomizations` section, so planned to allow the user to do it like this:

```js
"workbench.colorCustomizations": {
	"dart.closingLabels": "#ff0000"
},
```

Then in my code I'm doing this:

```ts
new vs.ThemeColor("dart.closingLabels")
```

This works fine, but I don't know how to set a default. Ideally I'd like to fall back to the `tab.inactiveForeground` colour (so that it has a reasonable default for any theme). However, I can't see a way to do this.

Is there a nice way to handle this? Or is the best thing just to look for `workbench.colorCustomizations.dart.closingLabels` in the settings and if it's not set, use the string  `tab.inactiveForeground` for the colour?

data.title: Added a `singleInstanceOnly` option in tasks, Fixes #32264
data.body:
Added a `singleInstanceOnly` option in `tasks.json`. 
Default value is `false`.

When this option is true, Then starting a task that is already running will kill the existing task and restart it.

When this option is false, It'll show the current behaviour, i.e. Give user an error about first terminating the task before starting it again.

I've not added tests yet because I am not sure, If I should write separate tests for it, or combine it with other tests like [this](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/c185e7d44eeacf5bf909131b0f661daaeff1ac59/src/vs/workbench/parts/tasks/test/electron-browser/configuration.test.ts#L628). I can write tests in any way you would prefer. 

This PR fixes #32264.

Regards
Ishan Jain

data.title: New function vscode.debug.startDebugging is defunct
data.body:
### Version Information:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.0
- OS Version: Microsoft Windows [Version 6.1.7601] (Windows 7)

### Related to:
The issue is related to [31266](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/31266), [30865](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/30865).

### Summary

New API `vscode.debug.startDebugging` is supposed to replace `vscode.commands.executeCommand("vscode.startDebug", launchConfiguration)` which does work correctly, but, with node.js "inspector" protocol, only with undocumented `type` `"node2"`, as explained in [31266](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/31266), [30865](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/30865). 

Not only `vscode.debug.startDebugging` does not reproduce correct functionality, but the symptoms look as if the `launchConfiguration` argument in `vscode.debug.startDebugging(launchConfiguration)` is ignored.

### Steps to Reproduce:

Code in extension:
```
        const launchConfiguration = {
            type: "node",  
            name: "launch",
            request: "launch",
            stopOnEntry: false,
            protocol: "auto"
        };
        launchConfiguration.program = ... // assign appropriate program
        vscode.debug.startDebugging(launchConfiguration);
```
The result of the call depends on the presence of the workspace file ".vscode/launch.json" of the target workspace using the extension. If the file is absent, the behavior is identical to the behavior when the user activates main menu item "Debug" => "Start Debugging" (F5): the user is requested for the choice and, if "node.js" is selected, the debugging starts with the currently opened JavaScript file (if any and if it is valid for the start of debugging).

**Important**: this is not the file specified as `launchConfiguration.program`. Basically, the behavior suggests that the entire structure passed as `launchConfiguration` is ignored.

If the file ".vscode/launch.json" is present, nothing happens, even if this file correctly prescribes debugging of the currently opened JavaScript file.

### Reproduces without extensions:
No (the issue is itself related to extension development)

data.title: extension installation using CLI leads to UnhandledPromiseRejectionWarning and hangs
data.body:
Installing any extension, using code CLI, like

`code --install-extension EditorConfig.EditorConfig`

leads to the following message and the command hangs
`
Found 'EditorConfig.EditorConfig' in the marketplace.
Installing...
(node:16346) UnhandledPromiseRejectionWarning: Unhandled promise rejection (rejection id: 1): TypeError: this._state.then is not a function
(node:16346) DeprecationWarning: Unhandled promise rejections are deprecated. In the future, promise rejections that are not handled will terminate the Node.js process with a non-zero exit code.
`
- VSCode Version: 1.15
- OS Version: Ubuntu 17.04, Fedora 26

Extensions can be installed from within the editor, without any problem.
